Educational Radio and Television
Richard S. Burdick
Managing Director
January 4, 1961
William G. Harley, President
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
Suite 1119
DuPont Circle Office Building
1346 Connecticut Avenue, N, W.
Washington S, D C.
Dear Bill;
In reviewing the minutes of the NAEB Board meeting held in San Francisco on
October 15, 1960, I noted certain inaccuracies in the report by legal counsel, Leonard
Marks. You will recall that I joined the meeting after Leonard Marks had made his
report, so therefore I did not become acquainted with it until reading the minutes
recently distributed .
The inaccuracies in the Leonard Marks report are of such significance and,
I assume, will be of such concern to the NAEB Board members who are concerned with
the representation by Cohn & Marks of a commercial applicant vs. an educational
applicant in the hearing for a licensee to operate VHF Channel 12, Delaware that I want
to take this opportunity to bring the corrections to your attention.
In paragraph one of his report, Mr. Marks states; * 'Educators in Philadelphia
feel that since there is no interest on the part of educational Interests in Delaware,
Including the University of Delaware, to obtain the station that this valuable VHF
station should be assigned to Philadelphia, where it could better serve educational
interests in that City."
There are two major inaccuracies in the above statement:
1) Philadelphia do not feel as stated by Mr. Marks. On the contrary, they are
greatly encouraged by the strength and volume of the support of the educational interests
in Delaware in respect to the WHYY, Inc. application for Channel 12. It is unfortunate
that the Leonard Marks statement gives the impression that Delaware educational
interests are not interested in seeing the station operated as an educational service,
merely because they are not themselves financially prepared to assume the full burden
of licensees, when in fact they have wholeheartedly endorsed the idea of the channel
to be operated for education on the premise that the operational responsibility will be
assumed by WHYY, Inc.
2) It is not and has never been the intent of WHYY, Inc. to have VHF Channel
12 assigned to Philadelphia; indeed, the FCC channel allocations preclude such a
reassignment. We recognize and honor the proprietary right of Delaware to retain the
channel within its own state boundaries and have no intentions of trying to hijack it.
Delaware educational, cultural and civic interests have endorsed our proposal to operate
the channel for the service of the entire tri-state area, with a studio to be located in
1622 Chestnut Street
Philadelphia 3, Pa.
